Introduction

Cervical insufficiency is a structural weakness of the cervix that predisposes to painless cervical dilation, which can lead to second-trimester pregnancy loss (<20 weeks gestation) or extremely preterm birth (<28 weeks gestation) in the absence of uterine contractions.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Cervical insufficiency occurs due to structural weakness of the cervix such that the increasing weight and pressure of a developing pregnancy causes spontaneous cervical dilation.  Most commonly, cervical insufficiency is caused by prior injury or trauma to the cervix, which compromises its structural integrity and decreases the cervical tensile strength.  Therefore, the major risk factors include:



  • Prior cervical excisional procedure (eg, cervical conization, loop electrosurgical excision procedure [LEEP]) for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia
  • Prior obstetric trauma (eg, cervical laceration)


Patients with prior second-trimester pregnancy loss or extremely preterm birth are also at risk, particularly if the prior delivery was associated with spontaneous, painless cervical dilation.  In rare cases, cervical insufficiency can be caused by inherent collagen disorders (eg, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) or congenital uterine abnormalities (eg, septate or bicornuate uterus).

Clinical presentation



The classic presentation of cervical insufficiency is cervical dilation in the absence of painful uterine contractions (ie, painless cervical dilation).  Patients may be completely asymptomatic or have the following mild symptoms:



  • Pelvic pressure or backache (due to fetal parts distending the upper vagina)
  • Change in vaginal discharge (increased discharge due to loss of the mucus plug)
  • Light vaginal bleeding (due to cervical dilation and effacement)


Depending on the timing of patient presentation, examination findings may include:



  • A soft, closed cervix (early) or dilated cervix â‰¥1 cm (later)
  • No uterine contractions on tocodynamometry (Occasionally, irregular contractions may be seen on tocodynamometry, but they are usually imperceptible to the patient.)
  • Bulging or prolapsing amniotic membranes into the endocervical canal or vagina
  • Rupture of membranes
  • Fetal parts in the upper vagina

Diagnosis



Cervical insufficiency can be diagnosed by obstetric history or abnormal findings in the current pregnancy.  Patients have a diagnosis of cervical insufficiency if they meet any of the following criteria:



  • History-based:  â‰¥2 prior consecutive, painless second-trimester losses/extremely preterm births
  • Ultrasonography based:  â‰¥1 prior painless second-trimester losses/extremely preterm birth PLUS a short cervix (â‰¤2.5 cm) on transvaginal ultrasonography at <24 weeks gestation in the current pregnancy
  • Examination based:  painless cervical dilation in the current pregnancy at 14-27 weeks gestation


An examination-based diagnosis is usually made in patients with mild symptoms (eg, pelvic pressure, vaginal bleeding).  These patients require evaluation with both physical examination and transvaginal ultrasonography.  However, the cervix can appear to have no dilation or effacement on digital cervical examination early in the course of cervical insufficiency.  Therefore, all patients require transvaginal ultrasonography; findings associated with cervical insufficiency include a short cervix, debris or sludge in the amniotic fluid, and cervical funneling.

Differential diagnosis



Cervical insufficiency must be differentiated from both miscarriage (or spontaneous abortion) and preterm labor, which have different management strategies for current and future pregnancies.



  • Miscarriage (or spontaneous abortion):  also presents with cervical dilation at <20 weeks gestation, but typically, vaginal bleeding and cramping progress to painful contractions
  • Preterm labor:  causes cervical dilation but is differentiated from cervical insufficiency by the presence of regular, painful contractions


Patients should also be evaluated for a urogenital tract infection (eg, group B Streptococcus, chlamydia, gonorrhea); inflammation can cause cervical change and light vaginal bleeding.  In addition, particularly for gonorrhea and chlamydia, the infection should be treated prior to management of cervical insufficiency to prevent creating a nidus for further infection.

Management



The primary goal of management in patients with cervical insufficiency is to prevent a preterm birth, this is accomplished with cerclage placement.  A cerclage (

figure 1
) is a permanent suture placed around the cervix to add tensile strength and maintain cervical length to prevent spontaneous cervical dilation.  The suture is removed at term to allow vaginal delivery.



The timing of cerclage placement depends on the clinical presentation:



  • In patients with a history-based diagnosis, prophylactic cerclage is placed at 12-14 weeks gestation to decrease the risk for recurrent second-trimester pregnancy loss.  Routine cervical length screening is not necessary after cerclage placement.
  • In patients with an ultrasonography-based diagnosis (ie, prior preterm birth plus short cervix in the current pregnancy), a therapeutic cerclage can be placed at up to 24 weeks gestation.
  • In patients with an examination-based diagnosis, "rescue" or "emergency" cerclage may be attempted.  Before placement of the cerclage, contraindications such as intraamniotic infection or ruptured membranes should be evaluated for as infection increases maternal morbidity.  In patients with prolapsed or bulging membranes, rescue cerclage placement has a high risk for iatrogenic membrane rupture and intraamniotic infection.  In addition, placing or maintaining a cerclage in patients at risk for imminent delivery can lead to cervical laceration.


Interventions that are no longer recommended because they do not decrease the rates of spontaneous preterm birth include pessary placement (insertion of a vaginal device to support the cervix) and strict activity restriction (ie, bed rest).  Pelvic rest (ie, avoidance of sexual activity) may be recommended after cerclage placement.

Prognosis



The prognosis depends on patient presentation and use of cerclage or progesterone supplementation.  Cerclage placement, particularly history-indicated cerclage placement at 12-14 weeks gestation, increases the likelihood of carrying the pregnancy to â‰¥34 weeks gestation.  However, significant cervical dilation and prolapsing of the amniotic membranes on examination are factors associated with a poor prognosis (ie, likely imminent delivery).



In subsequent pregnancies, the risk remains high for recurrent second-trimester pregnancy loss or an extremely preterm birth due to cervical insufficiency; either is likely to occur at earlier gestations.

Prevention



Primary prevention of cervical insufficiency avoids acquired causes of structural weakness of the cervix (eg, surgical or obstetric trauma to the cervix).  In general, vaccination against human papillomavirus (HPV) is recommended for all women because excisional procedures are a major risk factor for cervical insufficiency.



Secondary prevention (ie, spontaneous preterm birth prevention) begins with a thorough review of obstetric history at the initial prenatal visit to identify patients with a history of spontaneous preterm birth and those who meet the criteria for a history-based diagnosis of cervical insufficiency.

Summary



Cervical insufficiency (
